title: Ex Bluescope executive charged with obstructing ACCC
text:
The criminal charges laid against Mr Ellis are offences under the Criminal Code Act 1995 and carry a maximum penalty of two years’ imprisonment per offence.

The criminal charges of inciting the obstruction of a Commonwealth official brought against Mr Ellis are listed before the Downing Centre Local Court in Sydney on November 5.

The ACCC said the Commonwealth Department of Public Prosecutions had considered the alleged cartel offences, and decided not to commence criminal cartel proceedings against either BlueScope or Mr Ellis.

The separate civil cartel proceedings filed by the ACCC against BlueScope and Mr Ellis remain before the Federal Court.

BlueScope said on Tuesday it would not be appropriate to comment further because the matters are before the courts.

In those proceedings, the ACCC alleges that between September 2013 and June 2014, BlueScope and Mr Ellis attempted to induce various steel distributors in Australia and overseas manufacturers to enter agreements containing a price fixing provision.

In the civil penalty proceedings, the ACCC alleges that during the period under scrutiny, annual sales of flat steel products across the market were between $2.5 billion to $2.8 billion, with BlueScope having a $2 billion share, or around 75 per cent.

The ACCC alleges Mr Ellis held up to 11 separate meetings with competitors between September 2013 and March 2014 across Victoria, Taiwan and India.

Advertisement

The alleged strategy included the "carrot" of removing "early order offers" from their price list to bump the price of steel up by as much as 15 per cent and encourage their rivals to use the same price.

The alleged "stick" involved threatening to lodge anti-dumping complaints against rivals if they did not raise their prices to tie them up in regulatory red tape.

One of the biggest companies which the ACCC alleges Mr Ellis attempted to induce agreements with was JSW Steel, the steel arm of one of India's biggest industrial conglomerates, at a meeting on March 6, 2014 in India.

Other meetings alleged to have taken place were in Taiwan on February 26, 2014 with China Steel Corp, Yieh Phui Enterprise Co Ltd, and Chang Sheng Steel Co.

In the home market, the ACCC alleges that BlueScope attempted to induce agreements with Wright Steel Sales in Victoria, Selection Steel, Apex Steel, Southern Steel Group, Vulcan Steel, CMC Steel Distribution and Celhurst Pty Ltd, trading as Selwood Steel Trading
description: ACCC chairman Rod Sims says its the first time any individual has been charged with inciting the obstruction of officials in an ACCC investigation.
